newsitem.title: FRANCE: Russian poet and singer Okudzhava dies in Paris.
newsitem.headline: Russian poet and singer Okudzhava dies in Paris.

text.p: Russian poet and singer Bulat Okudzhava, whose dissident lyrics once filled stadiums with fans, has died in France. He was 73.
Okudzhava died on Thusday at Percy military hospital in Clamart in the Paris suburbs, a French armed forces spokeswoman said. The cause of death was not immediately disclosed.
French military hospitals are open to the general public, treating civilian patients who live nearby.
Although especially influential in the 1960s and 1970s, Okudzhava's simple melodies and moving lyrics, usually accompanied by acoustic guitar, attracted generations of fans.
Love, war and everyday life were the focus of his lyrics.
In one of his songs about Moscow's most famous streets, he sang: "Ah Arbat, my Arbat, you are my melody, you are my Fatherland, you are my joy and sorrow."

Born in Moscow in May 1924, Okudzhava served in World War Two and then became a school teacher. His songs and writing thrived during the political thaw in Russia introduced by Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev in the 1950s, and he later also wrote historical novels.
He was poetry editor of the Moscow Literary Gazette from 1956-64 and made the first of many trips to France in the late 1960s.
Half Georgian and half Armenian, Okudzhava was long out of favour with the Soviet communist regime, but won the approval of reform-minded authorities in the late 1980s.

In December 1994 he won the 10,000 pound ($15,000) Russian Booker literary prize, but did not attend the award ceremony because of poor health. He was also named a member of President Boris Yeltsin's council on culture and art.
In recent years he developed heart problems and kept a low public profile. He had heart surgery in the United States several years ago, and in August last year suffered a heart attack.

Ekho Moskva radio said he died from complications related to pneumonia and kidney failure. But Itar Tass news agency quoted his wife Olga as saying he died "from the psychological stress of loneliness".
